instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..

threads.title: [FUBAR]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Water Damaged
threads.message: Kinda stumped on where to go with this one.. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and the SMC area is getting really warm (and is shorted), however I do indeed have <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and a green light on the charger. I have gone back to the S5 enables and found 1.2v on pin 6 of <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> (supposed to be <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>)... I've also discovered I have 3.4v on pins 1,2 and 3 (but nothing in this area is shorted).. My assumption based on how fucked the area near the SMC looked is that the problem is in that area (image attached). All caps on that line are shorted and 2 have been removed because they were completely black and burned.. any help on how to go about repairing this?

threads.title: [FUBAR]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Water Damaged
threads.message: Looks like a short in the PCB. Scrape away the charred crap and hope the short goes away. Chance of this being fixable is pretty low though.

threads.title: [FUBAR]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Water Damaged
threads.message: Scratched it off and yeah, still shorted.. Probably just gonna call it a dead one cause I'd rather not put a ton of time into this

threads.title: [FUBAR]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Water Damaged
threads.message: Yeah, it is also in an area where there would be traces in the other layers so digging this short out will destroy the traces.
